body:
@scoder @matusvalo [This change](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4498) killed some nasty dynamic `build_ext` subclassing that PyYAML's been doing since the dawn of time (see https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/601 and https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/blob/6.0/setup.py#L174-L238). The most immediate issue is just that the `cython_sources` method from `old_build_ext` that PyYAML's subclass was calling is no longer available- I tried a few different ways of patching it on with no success (various issues around missing instance data on either the command or the extension by the time `get_source_files` is called). 

A couple of questions:
1) Would you consider a reasonably simple change to emulate the `cython_sources` method from `old_build_ext` (to keep already-released PyYAML `build_ext` subclasses working on 3.0.0a10+ without modification)? That's assuming I can come up with one- so far, that's not looking good...
2) Curious what the long-term plan is for `old_build_ext`? I can make things work again in future PyYAML releases without rewiring all the ancient build code just by swapping in `old_build_ext` (eg https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/pull/602), but not sure how long it'll be around.

Thanks!

(I can open an issue for this, but if the answers to the above are "no" and "not very long", not much point :wink: )

_Originally posted by @nitzmahone in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4498#issuecomment-1011573018_

comment_data.body:
> The most immediate issue is just that the `cython_sources` method from `old_build_ext` that PyYAML's subclass was calling is no longer available- I tried a few different ways of patching it on with no success (various issues around missing instance data on either the command or the extension by the time `get_source_files` is called).

Thanks for reporting this. The way that function is being used in PyYAML seems to intend replacing the .pyx sources by the generated .c sources. If that's it, then calling `cythonize()` instead might work. Not even sure if you need to inherit from Cython's `build_ext` in that case at all (or could simply use the one from setuptools).


>     1. Would you consider a reasonably simple change to emulate the `cython_sources` method from `old_build_ext` (to keep already-released PyYAML `build_ext` subclasses working on 3.0.0a10+ without modification)? That's assuming I can come up with one- so far, that's not looking good...

If it's just about calling `cythonize()`, then it's probably ok for us to re-add that to keep it working.


>     2. Curious what the long-term plan is for `old_build_ext`? I can make things work again in future PyYAML releases without rewiring all the ancient build code just by swapping in `old_build_ext` (eg [WIP keep PyYAML build working on Cython3.0.0a10+ yaml/pyyaml#602](https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/pull/602)), but not sure how long it'll be around.

It's an annoying piece of outdated and duplicated code, not very well tested, and thus likely to break silently at some point. In terms of project management, that probably means that it will stick around forever, but not necessarily in a usable state for very long.

Thanks for the response and thoughts. I did mess around with just calling `cythonize` from a `cython_sources` method added to  the new `build_ext` but ran into a bunch of other failures that look like the extension we're passing in hasn't been filled out enough yet. I'm guessing it's related to one or both of the pyyaml setup code also subclassing `Extension` and that the new Cython `build_ext` doesn't use all the same hook points that the old one did.

I'll keep playing with it- I'm hoping to find a simple and acceptable change that'll keep the existing releases working on Cython 3.0, since we recently made Cython a hard build dep in pyproject but didn't pin a version in there. Worst case, I can just do patch releases on those branches and pin the pyproject build dep to `Cython<3.0`, then solve the problem "properly" for new releases.

@nitzmahone 
> Worst case, I can just do patch releases on those branches and pin the pyproject build dep to `Cython<3.0`, then solve the problem "properly" for new releases.

Unfortunately, this only solves the problem as far forward as Python 3.12.x, but not for the (in-development) Python 3.13. `Cython<3.0` has a dependency on the deprecated `cgi` module (imported by `Cython.Tempita._tempita`), which was removed from the stdlib ~ a month ago. (See @vstinner's python/cpython@08d5923896.)

So in Python 3.13 as of last month, `Cython==0.29.35` fails with anything and everything due to the missing `cgi` module, and `Cython>=3.0.0b1` fails to build `PyYAML==6.0` due to the unconditional use of `build_ext.cython_sources()` in the latter's `setup.py`.

> So in Python 3.13 as of last month, Cython==0.29.35 fails with anything and everything due to the missing cgi module

importing `cgi` module was removed in the following commit: https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/54b92e3d4f75225c55609076afd2d901be8326d2. I think it will be fixed in Cython `0.29.36` release.

> Looks like that SHA-1 somehow acquired a rogue 'z' on the end

Ah snap! Fixed my comment.

> I take it there will be an 0.29.36 release, then?

I cannot tell you with 100% confidence because I **am not deciding about releases**, but I suppose there will be release since it was merged to 0.29.x branch. @scoder can provide you more accurate information about future releases...

@matusvalo 

>> I take it there will be an 0.29.36 release, then?
>
> I suppose there will be release since it was merged to 0.29.x branch. 

Ah, good point. And looking at the most recent entries in the #5449 history, I'd say this counts as a firm yes:

![image](https://github.com/cython/cython/assets/538020/30c9d294-5768-46b1-b7e4-a6a89b908a1d)

Just wanted to add to the discussion, since this is the only place I can find ongoing discussion regarding 0.29.36 (even in the mailing list). I need 0.29.36 for PyPy support as noted in https://github.com/cython/cython/milestone/96?closed=1. I'm sure the maintainers are very busy. I'd be grateful if some clarification could be provided on the plan to release 0.29.36.

Sorry this isn't directly relevant to the bug itself and creating noise for all subscribers.

> I'd be grateful if some clarification could be provided on the plan to release 0.29.36.

@wbarnha Cython 0.29.36 was released.

PyYAML should switch to using `Cython.Build.build_ext` (it will soon enough have to jettison `distutils` with Python 3.12 later this year and it might as well also jettison `Cython.Distutils`).

One issue with this is, currently PyYAML intentionally makes Cython a build-time only dependency. At [Distributing Cython modules](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#distributing-cython-modules) Cython documents a method to accomplish this using `Cython.Build.cythonize` (the documentation uses `USE_CYTHON` instead of `with_cython` used in PyYAML). Cython also documents `Cython.Build.build_ext` but only as a hard dependency all the time. Can the Cython documentation be updated to document a build-time only dependency using the `Cython.Build.build_ext` method?

Any maybe [Migrating from Cython 0.29 to 3.0](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/migrating_to_cy30.html) can also mention how to port away from `Cython.Distutils` interfaces.

Yep, that's the plan- also why I didn't want to "sorta" add support for Cython 3 by switching to `old_build_ext`- that's just giving us more excuses to defer fixing it properly.

At least in PyYAML's case, the complexity is because PyYAML was actually further subclassing Cython's distutils stuff, and relying on a bunch of internal state and method call orders that differ greatly under `new_build_ext`- I messed around for awhile ~18mo ago trying to get the distutils stuff working again under that, but IIRC it was going to require some pretty major hackery to get it to work (and again being very brittle/fragile and still relying on distutils anyway). Now that it's pretty stable and we've got better ways to pass config into the PEP517 backend, I'd much rather spend that time just making it work right sans distutils. :laughing:

I'm not sure how many other projects are relying on the distutils stuff, but at least in our case, more docs wouldn't really help much. The build backend integration seems pretty straightforward, we just need to decide which of our own config knobs we want to preserve and implement support for whatever's needed before we hand back off to Cython's build backend, and decide if we want to do any further magic to better support the truly "Cython optional" cases it used to (eg, in-tree backend wrapper to allow native-only PEP517 builds sans Cython).

@nitzmahone: Since `distutils` has been a part of `setuptools` for quite sometime now, PyYAML could consider piecemeal transitional changes. So long as `setuptools` is imported first, `distutils` imported after that point should reliably exist (at least until `setuptools` starts dumping stuff). PyYAML could incrementally:
1. switch to `old_build_ext` continuing to use `cython_sources`
2. switch to `new_build_ext` and `cythonize` (in place of `cython_sources`; the API is similar: filtering an `Extension` `sources` vs. filtering an `Extension`)
3. switch away from `distools`

Somewhere along the way PyYAML may also want to avoid `new_build_ext` by using the stock `setuptools.command.build_ext` and directly using `cythonize` since that seems to have better documentation and may be simpler.

I am not sure if that is all completely thought out since there are some dependencies but I think there may be a viable approach in there somewhere. And a total rewrite could be considered as well but without the urgency so it could be done right without rocking the boat too much.

title: Switch to "new_build_ext" broke PyYAML
